articles.title: From bland to bold - how these women are ditching beige to spark joy
articles.summary: From kitsch mirrors to neon pink walls, a pop of colour could brighten up your winter.
articles.content:
From bland to bold - how these women are ditching beige to spark joy

3 hours ago Share Save Alice Cullinane West Midlands Share Save

Rachel Verney Rachel Verney started renovating her home with colour during the pandemic in 2020

While some get a boost of happiness by exercising and getting enough sleep, others are turning to interior design with bold paint and eye-catching patterns. It is a craze known as "dopamine decor", which has more than 70,000 posts on TikTok, and involves adding bright, quirky items to your home for a happiness boost. Rachel Verney shares decor inspiration videos of her colourful Surrey home to more than 800,000 followers on social media and she saw her popularity boom when she bought a bright orange sofa. Known as The Shoestring Home, millions watch her renovation videos as she aims to make "aesthetic accessible" and help people create colourful spaces on a budget.

"It's my happy place when I work on a project," she said. "Sometimes I feel like an imposter as I'm not qualified to do the job." On Facebook, she has experienced "division" over her interiors as some find the designs too bold. But while she might not have a degree in interior design, her ideas have been a hit with younger viewers and she has made content creation her full-time job over the past year. "Everything is so gloomy and the world is a bit of a scary place at the moment - houses want to be joyful," she said.

Rachel Verney Patterned bedding and framed graphics can boost the colour in bedrooms

Dopamine is a neurotransmitter that plays a crucial role in our brain's reward and pleasure systems. Often referred to as the "feel-good" hormone, it influences mood, motivation, and attention. Psychologist Dr Natasha Sharma said vivid colours produced small dopamine hits, which, in uncertain times, provided a sense of optimism and reward. She said dopamine decor allowed people to "externalise" their identity and boost their mood, giving a "heightened sense of wellbeing". Dr Sharma, from Wolverhampton, added that a home dominated by grey or neutral tones could result in "feelings of emotional flatness".

Alice Cullinane/BBC Nicola Brighton sells bold mirrors and wall prints to decor lovers

Nicola Brighton is among those making a living from the trend, creating kitsch prints and neon mirrors in unique shapes which are stocked in stores across the UK and US. Since 2022, her business Printed Weird, which is based in Birmingham, has grown 62% and her designs frequently sell out as customers look for nostalgia to add to their homes. "When you come home from work and you've had a rubbish day, you can just look at things that bring you joy and happiness," Nicola said. She started her business from her mum's spare bedroom seven years ago, fuelled by a love for colourful decor and a mission to put affordable items on the market. "Through what you love, why not put that silliness on your wall? It's an extension of your personality and will bring you joy," she said.

Rachel Verney Brightly coloured rooms are believed to activate "neural pathways" linked to reward and vitality

But while Google searches for dopamine decor have risen more than 110% in the past year, estate agents warned the trend could put off potential buyers. Paul Fox Estate Agents, based in Lincolnshire, recommended a neutral colour scheme over bold hues, adding "timeless" shades helped sell homes quickly. "First impressions are everything, so by ensuring that the home is painted in popular colours you are likely to attract buyers," the agent said.

Alice Cullinane/BBC Jodie Edmonds moved into her first house in July and has filled it with bright colours

Despite the agent's advice, new homeowners like Jodie Edmonds have decided to add personality to their walls. "I'm not bothered when it comes to reselling, people have different tastes and can change the decor," she said. For Jodie, a colourful scheme is a way to express herself and make guests feel happier. "A grey house would make me feel low, a bright house makes me feel motivated and inspired," she said.

How to add dopamine decor to your home without breaking the bank

Rachel Verney recommends you introduce colours you love into your decor by starting with items like cushions and rugs, and not being afraid to mix colours and patterns Simple touches to practical items go a long way - vinyl wrap your fridge in an exciting pattern, paint your appliances and radiators any colour of the rainbow or add a fun printed shower curtain and quirky bathmat to a boring bathroom Get crafty to create affordable dupes of your favourite brands, like adding bows to cushion covers or updating candlesticks Shop second hand and upcycle pieces from charity shops and Facebook Marketplace to save money and items from landfill Add plants to shelves, mantlepieces and uninspired corners to boost your mood. If your fingers are not green, consider botanical prints on wallpapers, rugs or bedding to bring warmth and tranquillity to your home
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a positive lifestyle trend—dopamine decor—that uses bold colors in home interiors to boost mood and wellbeing, supported by psychological insights. It shows broad societal relevance as many people seek ways to improve mental health and happiness through their living spaces, and includes practical, accessible advice. While not a major scientific breakthrough, it offers meaningful, tangible benefits to a wide audience's emotional health and quality of life.
articles.personality_title: Bright colors at home: how dopamine decor is lifting moods and changing spaces
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – During the pandemic, many people looked for ways to improve their happiness and wellbeing at home. One popular trend that grew on social media is called "dopamine decor." This means using bright colors and fun patterns in home decoration to make people feel happier.

**What happened** – Rachel Verney from Surrey started sharing videos of her colorful home on social media in 2020. She gained over 800,000 followers by showing how to decorate with bold colors on a budget. Her bright orange sofa became especially popular. Meanwhile, Nicola Brighton in Birmingham turned this trend into a business, selling neon mirrors and colorful prints. More people, like new homeowner Jodie Edmonds, are choosing lively colors to express themselves and feel more motivated in their homes.

**Impact** – Psychologists explain that bright colors can trigger dopamine, a brain chemical that makes us feel good. Using dopamine decor helps people feel more positive, especially during uncertain times. It lets people show their personality and improve their mood. However, some estate agents warn that very bold colors might make it harder to sell a home quickly, as many buyers prefer neutral tones.

**What's next step** – Experts suggest starting small by adding colorful cushions, rugs, or plants to rooms. People can also get creative by repainting old furniture or shopping second-hand to save money. This trend may continue growing as more people look for easy ways to brighten their living spaces and feel better inside their homes.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Adding bright colors and fun patterns at home, known as dopamine decor, can boost mood and make living spaces more joyful and personal without needing a big budget.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Rachel Verney, du Surrey, a commencé à partager des vidéos de sa maison colorée en 2020. Elle a gagné plus de 800 000 abonnés en montrant comment décorer avec des couleurs audacieuses sans dépenser beaucoup. Son canapé orange vif est devenu très célèbre. De son côté, Nicola Brighton à Birmingham a créé une entreprise qui vend des miroirs néon et des imprimés colorés. De plus en plus de personnes, comme Jodie Edmonds, choisissent des couleurs vives pour s'exprimer et se sentir motivées chez elles.

**Impact** – Les psychologues expliquent que les couleurs vives stimulent la dopamine, une substance chimique du cerveau qui procure du plaisir. La déco dopamine aide à se sentir plus positif, surtout en période d'incertitude. Elle permet aussi d'exprimer sa personnalité et d'améliorer son humeur. Cependant, certains agents immobiliers préviennent que des couleurs trop fortes peuvent compliquer la revente d'une maison, car beaucoup d'acheteurs préfèrent des tons neutres.

articles.personality_title_es: Colores brillantes en casa: cómo la decoración dopamina eleva el ánimo y transforma los espacios
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Durante la pandemia, muchas personas buscaron formas de mejorar su felicidad y bienestar en casa. Una tendencia popular en redes sociales es la "decoración dopamina", que consiste en usar colores vivos y patrones divertidos para hacer que los espacios sean más alegres.

**Qué pasó** – Rachel Verney, de Surrey, comenzó a compartir videos de su casa colorida en 2020. Consiguió más de 800,000 seguidores mostrando cómo decorar con colores llamativos sin gastar mucho. Su sofá naranja brillante fue especialmente popular. Mientras tanto, Nicola Brighton en Birmingham convirtió esta tendencia en un negocio, vendiendo espejos de neón y estampados coloridos. Más personas, como la nueva propietaria Jodie Edmonds, están eligiendo colores vivos para expresarse y sentirse motivadas en sus hogares.

**Impacto** – Los psicólogos explican que los colores brillantes pueden activar la dopamina, una sustancia química en el cerebro que nos hace sentir bien. La decoración dopamina ayuda a que las personas se sientan más positivas, especialmente en tiempos inciertos. Permite mostrar la personalidad y mejorar el ánimo. Sin embargo, algunos agentes inmobiliarios advierten que los colores muy fuertes pueden dificultar la venta rápida de una casa, ya que muchos compradores prefieren tonos neutros.

**Próximo paso** – Los expertos sugieren empezar con pequeños detalles como cojines, alfombras o plantas coloridas. También se puede ser creativo pintando muebles viejos o comprando de segunda mano para ahorrar. Esta tendencia podría seguir creciendo a medida que más personas buscan formas fáciles de alegrar sus hogares y sentirse mejor.

**Frase clave** – Añadir colores brillantes y patrones divertidos en casa, llamado decoración dopamina, puede mejorar el ánimo y hacer que los espacios sean más alegres y personales sin necesidad de gastar mucho.
